On H introduce the quadratic functional  

J(f)= ∫_{−1}^{1} (f''(x))² dx .

We show that the minimum of J on H equals 15 and determine the unique minimiser.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.   Existence of a minimiser
--------------------------------------------------------------------
H is a closed affine subspace of the Hilbert space  
H²(−1,1) with inner product ⟨u,v⟩ = ∫_{−1}^{1} u''(x)v''(x)dx .
Because J is the squared norm coming from this inner product, it is strictly
convex and weakly lower–semicontinuous, hence it attains its minimum on the
non-empty set H.  The minimiser is unique.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.   Euler–Lagrange equation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let g∈H be the minimiser and
h be an arbitrary C²–function with h(±1)=0 and ∫_{−1}^{1}h=0.
For every real ε, g+εh still belongs to H, so

0 = d/dε|_{ε=0} J(g+εh)
  = 2 ∫_{−1}^{1} g'' h'' dx.                       (1)

Thus g'' is L²–orthogonal to {h'': h as above}.

Introduce three Lagrange multipliers α,β,γ for the three linear constraints,
and consider  

F(f)= ∫_{−1}^{1}(f'')²dx + α∫_{−1}^{1}f(x)dx
      + β(f(1)-1) + γ(f(−1)-1).

Take a C² variation f+εη with η arbitrary but η(±1)=0.
Computing the first variation and integrating by parts twice gives

0 = dF|_{ε=0}
  = 2∫_{−1}^{1} f^{(4)} η dx + α∫_{−1}^{1} η dx
    + 2[f''η']_{−1}^{1} .                      (2)

Because η is arbitrary in the interior of the interval, (2) implies

f^{(4)}(x) = −α/2 =: k (constant).              (3)

Because η' can be chosen freely at ±1, the boundary term in (2) forces

f''(−1) = f''(1) = 0.                           (4)

Hence the minimiser g is a quartic polynomial satisfying (3)–(4).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.   Determining the quartic polynomial
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Write  

g(x)= ax⁴+bx³+cx²+dx+e   (a=k/24).

Then  

g''(x)= 12ax²+6bx+2c.

Using (4):

12a + 6b + 2c = 0,  
12a − 6b + 2c = 0  ⇒  b = 0,  c = −6a.        (5)

The boundary values g(±1)=1 give

a + c + d + e = 1,  
a + c − d + e = 1.                            (6)

From (6) we get d = 0 and −5a + e = 1.        (7)

Finally the integral condition

∫_{−1}^{1} g(x)dx = 0

together with (5)–(7) yields

2a/5 − 4a + 2 + 10a = 0  ⇒  a = −5/16.        (8)

Consequently  

b = d = 0,   c = 15/8,   e = −9/16.

Thus  

g(x)= −\frac{5}{16}x^{4} + \frac{15}{8}x^{2} - \frac{9}{16}.   (9)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.   The minimum value of the functional
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For (9) we have  

g''(x)= \frac{15}{4}(1−x^{2}).                 (10)

Therefore  

J(g)= (15/4)² ∫_{−1}^{1}(1−x^{2})² dx

     = (225/16)· 2(1 − 2/3 + 1/5)
     = (225/16)· 16/15
     = 15.                                     (11)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.   Optimality and uniqueness
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Let f∈H be arbitrary and write h=f−g (so h(±1)=0, ∫ h=0).
Then by (1) the cross term vanishes:

∫_{−1}^{1} g'' h'' dx = 0.                    (12)

Hence  

J(f)= ∫ (g''+h'')²

Equality occurs iff ∫(h'')²=0, i.e. h''=0, so h is linear.
Because h(±1)=0, this linear function is identically zero; thus f=g.

6.   Conclusion

For every twice continuously differentiable
f : ℝ→ℝ with ∫_{−1}^{1}f(x)dx =0 and f(±1)=1,

∫_{−1}^{1} (f''(x))² dx ≥ 15,

⇔      (n+1)^a −1 ≤ x < (n+2)^a −1.                         (2)

At the same time x belongs to the strip  

        a n ≤ x < a(n+1).                                    (3)

Hence x must lie in the intersection of (2) and (3).
Denote  

        I_n = [a n , a(n+1)) ,
        J_n = [(n+1)^a-1 , (n+2)^a-1).

We need I_n ∩ J_n ≠ ∅.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Determination of the indices n which give a non–empty intersection
--------------------------------------------------------------------

(i)  n = −1  

    I_{−1}= [−a,0),  J_{−1}= [−1,0).  
    Because a≥2, I_{−1} contains J_{−1}; the intersection is the whole
    interval [−1,0).  
    (The left end −1 is admissible, for it keeps b^{a}+x ≥ 0 when b=1.)

(ii) n = 0  

    I_0=[0,a),  J_0=[0,2^a-1).  
    I_0⊂J_0, so we obtain the interval [0,a).

(iii) n ≥ 1  
     For the intersection to be non–empty we need

        (n+1)^a-1 < a(n+1).                                  (4)

     Because a≥2, the function t↦t^a grows faster than the linear
     function t↦a t; consequently (4) fails once its left–hand side
     exceeds the right–hand side.  Routine checking gives

     • a = 2 : (4) is still true for n = 1 (because 2·2 – 2² +1 = 1>0)
               and false for n ≥ 2;

     • a ≥ 4 : (4) is already false for n = 1 (indeed 2^a > 2a+1).

     Hence

     – when a = 2 an extra interval occurs for n = 1, namely
         I_1∩J_1 = [3,4);

     – when a ≥ 4 there are no further intersections.



So (1) forces  

   x ∈ [−1,0) ∪ [0,a)   (all even a),  
   and, only when a=2, an additional piece [3,4).



--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Sufficiency: each of the obtained intervals works for every b
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Write t = x/b^{a} (so |t| ≤ 1 because x ≥ −1).

A convenient form of L(b) is  

        L(b)=⌊\,b^{a}(1+t)^{1/a}⌋.                           (5)

We treat separately the three possible locations of x.

-------------------------------------------------------------
A.  −1 ≤ x < 0   (then ⌊x/a⌋ = −1)
-------------------------------------------------------------
Here −1 ≤ t < 0.  For 0<r<1 the Bernoulli inequality gives  

        (1+t)^{r} ≥ 1+t.                                    (6)

With r = 1/a we deduce from (6)

        (1+t)^{1/a} ≥ 1 + t ≥ 1 − 1/b^{a}.                  

Multiplying by b^{a} we obtain  

        b^{a} − 1 ≤ b^{a}(1+t)^{1/a} < b^{a}.               

Hence, by (5), L(b)=b^{a}−1 = R(b).

-------------------------------------------------------------
B.  0 ≤ x < a        (then ⌊x/a⌋ = 0)
-------------------------------------------------------------
Now 0 ≤ t < a/b^{a} ≤ 1.  Concavity of (1+t)^{1/a} yields  

        1 < (1+t)^{1/a} < 1 + t/a.                          (7)

Multiplying by b^{a} and recalling t = x/b^{a} we get  

        b^{a} < b^{a}(1+t)^{1/a} < b^{a} + x/a < b^{a}+1.

Thus L(b)=b^{a}=R(b).

-------------------------------------------------------------
C.  a = 2,    3 ≤ x < 4      (here ⌊x/2⌋ = 1)
-------------------------------------------------------------
Put y = x/b^{2} (so 0.75 ≤ y < 4/b^{2} ≤ 1).  
For 0 ≤ y ≤ 1 we have the two-sided estimate  

        1 + y/2 − y^{2}/8 ≤ √{1+y} < 1 + y/2.                (8)

Multiplying (8) by b^{2} gives

        b^{2}+1 < b^{2}√{1+y} < b^{2}+2.                   

Consequently b^{2}+1 ≤ L(b) ≤ b^{2}+1, i.e. L(b)=b^{2}+1=R(b).



--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Failure outside the found intervals
--------------------------------------------------------------------

If x < −1 the radicand 1+x (when b=1) becomes negative.
If x ≥ a and x ≠ 3,4 when a=2, then with b=1 equality (1) is violated.
Finally, if x is a non–zero multiple of a, then for large b the term
b^{a}(1+t)^{1/a} stays strictly below b^{a}+x/a, hence
⌊·⌋ drops by one and equality again fails.

So no other x can satisfy the required identity.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Complete description of the solution set
--------------------------------------------------------------------

Let a be an even positive integer.

•  If a = 2 :

       x ∈ [−1,2)  or  x ∈ [3,4).

•  If a ≥ 4 :

       x ∈ [−1, a).

All these numbers, and only these, fulfil  

        ⌊\,b^{a-1}\sqrt[a]{b^{a}+x}\,⌋
        = b^{a}+⌊x/a⌋       for every positive integer b.



Final answer.

Let n be large and τ∈T_n arbitrary.  
Write

C = {x∈[n] : x lies on a (directed) cycle of τ},    m = |C|,                     
h = max { k≥0 : τ^k(x)∉C for some x∈[n] } .

Thus m is the number of cyclic points of τ and h is the largest
distance (pre–period) of a point to the set C.

1.  A simple counting argument  
   After h steps every element of [n] is already on a cycle, so
   τ^{h+q}=τ^{h} whenever q is a multiple of the least common multiple
   of the lengths of the cycles contained in C.  Consequently

                     ord(τ) ≤ h + L                      (1)

   where  

                     L = lcm {lengths of the cycles of τ} .

2.  Bounding L  
   Restrict τ to the set C (|C|=m).  
   There it is a permutation, so L is the order of a permutation of m
   letters; hence

                     L ≤ f(m) ≤ f(n-h)                 (2)

   because m ≤ n-h and f is non–decreasing.

   Combining (1) and (2),

          ord(τ) ≤ h + f(n-h)                          (3)

   It remains to show

          h + f(n-h) < f(n) + n^{0.501}.               (4)

   The estimate will be done separately for “small’’ and “large’’ h.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
A quantitative estimate for f

Landau (1903) proved

       exp((1-ε)√{m log m}) ≤ f(m) ≤ exp((1+ε)√{m log m})    (5)

for every ε>0 and all m ≥ m_0(ε).  
Fix ε=0.01 and assume n≥N_0 so that (5) is valid for every m≤n.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Case h ≤ n^{0.501}

Here f(n-h) ≤ f(n), so (3) gives

         ord(τ) ≤ f(n) + h ≤ f(n) + n^{0.501},            (6)

and (4) is proved in this range.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Case h > n^{0.501}

Put α = h/n ; then α ≥ n^{-0.499}.  
Because f is increasing, (3) and (4) are equivalent to

        f(n) – f(n-h) ≥ h – n^{0.501}.                    (7)

We estimate the left side with (5).  Using log(n-h) < log n,

log f(n) − log f(n-h)
    ≥ 0.99√{n log n} − 1.01√{(n-h) log n}
    = √{n log n}·[0.99 − 1.01√{1-α}].

For 0<α≤1/2 one has 1−√{1-α} ≥ α/2, whence

   0.99 − 1.01√{1-α} ≥ 0.49α ≥ 0.49 n^{-0.499}.           (8)

Thus

        log(f(n)/f(n-h)) ≥ 0.49 n^{-0.499}√{n log n}
                          = 0.49 n^{0.001}√{log n}.        (9)

For sufficiently large n the right side of (9) exceeds 2 log n, hence

                 f(n) ≥ n^{2} f(n-h).                     (10)

Therefore

        f(n) − f(n-h) ≥ (1 − n^{-2})f(n) ≥ ½ f(n).        (11)

Because √{n log n} ≫ log n, (5) implies f(n) > n^{10} for large n, so

                ½ f(n) > n ≥ h  (> n^{0.501}).            (12)

Combining (11) and (12) we obtain

        f(n) − f(n-h) ≥ h − n^{0.501},                    (13)

which is exactly the desired inequality (7).

-------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Completion of the proof

Inequality (4) has been verified in both cases.  Consequently, for
every τ∈T_n

            ord(τ) < f(n) + n^{0.501}                     (14)

once n is larger than the fixed constant N_0 chosen above.
Taking the maximum over τ gives

                 g(n) < f(n) + n^{0.501}

for all sufficiently large n, completing the proof.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer.
For all sufficiently large integers n one has  
                g(n) < f(n) + n^{0.501}.

Let  

•  τ be an arbitrary map in Tn ,  
•  C(τ)   the set of points which lie on (directed) cycles of τ,  
•  h(τ)    the maximal distance of a point of [n] from C(τ) ( “height’’ of the forest which is attached to the cycles),  
•  λ(τ)   the least positive integer for which τ λ acts as the identity on C(τ) (the eventual period).

                                                             (1)  |C(τ)|+h(τ)≤n.

Indeed, the longest directed path which starts outside C(τ) and ends in C(τ) contains h(τ) different non-cyclic vertices which are not counted in |C(τ)|.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  The number of different powers of τ  

Every power τ k (k ≥0) acts identically on all vertices which are at distance ≥k from C(τ).  
Consequently the sequence (τ k ) k≥0 stabilises after h(τ) steps and then becomes periodic
with period λ(τ).  Thus

                                                             (2)  ord(τ)=h(τ)+λ(τ).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  λ(τ) is bounded by the Landau function

Restricted to C(τ) the map τ is a permutation of |C(τ)| points whose order is λ(τ).
Extending this permutation by fixed points on the remaining letters we obtain an element
of Sn−h(τ) having the same order.  Therefore

                                                             (3)  λ(τ) ≤ f(|C(τ)|) ≤ f(n−h(τ)).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A convenient analytic estimate for f

Landau proved that there are positive constants A<B such that for all sufficiently large m   

                                               A√{m log m} ≤ log f(m) ≤ B√{m log m}.               (4)

(The lower bound can be obtained constructively from the product of the primes not exceeding
√{m log m}; the upper bound follows from Stirling’s formula, but we shall only use the
lower one.)

From (4) we shall need two easy consequences.

Lemma 1 (fast growth of f).  
If m is large and s≥m 0.501  then   

                                                             f(m+s) ≥ (s+1)·f(m).              (5)

Proof.  
Put g(x)=√{x log x}.  For x≥m we have  

                           g′(x)= (log x+1) /(2√{x log x}) ≥ ½√{log m}/√x.

Hence for each such x   

                g(x+1)−g(x) ≥ ½√{log m}/√{x+1} ≥ ½√{log m}/√{2m}.

Summing this inequality for x=m,…,m+s−1 yields  

      g(m+s)−g(m) ≥ s· ½√{log m}/√{2m} ≥ ¼ s· √{log m}/√m.              (6)

If s≥m 0.501  then the right–hand side of (6) is ≥c log(s+1) with a fixed c>0,
whence by (4)  

               log f(m+s)−log f(m) ≥ log(s+1)  ⇒ f(m+s) ≥ (s+1)f(m). ∎



Lemma 2 (size comparison).  
For all large m one has                 f(m) > m².                                    (7)

This follows at once from (4) because √{m log m} > 2 log m when m is large.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Reduction to a one–variable maximisation

Put  
                       Φn(h)=h+f(n−h) (0≤h≤n).

By (2) and (3) we have  ord(τ) ≤ Φn(h(τ));  consequently  

                       g(n) ≤ max_{0≤h≤n} Φn(h).                                 (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Evaluating the maximum

Split the range of h into two parts.

(A)  h ≤ n 0.501 .  
Here Φn(h) ≤ h+f(n) ≤ f(n)+n 0.501 .

(B)  h ≥ n 0.501 .  
Because of (1) we have n−h ≥ n 0.499 , so Lemma 2 gives f(n−h) > n ≥ h.  
By Lemma 1 (with m=n−h and s=h) we obtain

                f(n) ≥ (h+1)·f(n−h) > h·f(n−h).                            (9)

Hence   f(n−h) ≤ f(n)/h   and therefore  

       Φn(h)=h+f(n−h) ≤ h+f(n)/h ≤ f(n)+1 ≤ f(n)+n 0.501 .                (10)

(The last inequality uses h≥n 0.501 ≥1 and the fact that f(n) dominates every polynomial for large n.)

Combining (8), (A) and (B) we have shown that for all sufficiently large n

                       g(n) ≤ f(n)+n 0.501 .

Since both g(n) and f(n) are integers, this inequality is in fact strict.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer.
For every sufficiently large positive integer n,  

                                     g(n) < f(n)+n^{0.501}.

Let  

 •  τ be an arbitrary self–map of [n]  
 •  d(τ)   the length of the longest directed path that ends in a cycle  
 •  C(τ)   the set of the elements which lie on the cycles of τ,  |C(τ)| = c(τ).

Write τk = τ∘ … ∘τ   (k–times) and put  
L(τ) = ord(τ)  (= the number of distinct maps among τ,τ²,τ³,…).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A general upper bound for L(τ)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For every x ∈ [n] the sequence (τk(x))k≥0 is eventually periodic.
After d(τ) steps every element has reached a cycle, and from that
moment on the map behaves like a permutation of the set C(τ).  Hence  

                L(τ) ≤ d(τ)+ ord(σ),                     (1)

where σ is the permutation τ|C(τ).  
Call  

                f(t) = max{ ord(π) : π∈S_t }.  

Inequality (1) gives  

                L(τ) ≤ d(τ) + f(c(τ)).                   (2)

Because c(τ) ≤ n and f is increasing,

                L(τ) ≤ d(τ) + f(n).                      (3)

If d(τ) ≤ n^0.501 formula (3) already yields  

                L(τ) ≤ f(n)+n^0.501,                     (4)

so the desired theorem is proved in this case.
Hence, from now on suppose

                d := d(τ) > n^{0.501}.                  (5)



--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  A permutation contains almost every point
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because a directed path of length d uses d vertices that are **not**
on a cycle, we have  

                c := c(τ) = n-d  .                       (6)

With d > n^{0.501} we still have c = n-d ≥ n - n^{0.501} → ∞, so
c is large.



--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Two estimates we shall use
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A)  (Landau, 1903) log f(m) = (1+o(1))√{m log m}.                    (7)

B)  (Chebyshev/Prime Number Theorem)  
    For every sufficiently large t there is a prime in (½t , t].     (8)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  A prime that does **not** divide ord(σ)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Put ℓ := ord(σ); by definition ℓ ≤ f(c) ≤ f(n).

If all primes not exceeding d divided ℓ, then the *primorial*

                P(d) = ∏_{p≤d} p

would satisfy P(d) | ℓ ≤ f(n).  
But, by well–known estimates,  

                log P(d) = (1+o(1)) d      (Mertens)

while, by (7), log f(n) = (1+o(1))√{n log n}.

For d > n^{0.501} we have d ≫ √{n log n}, so P(d) > f(n) for large n,
a contradiction.  Therefore

  there exists a prime q ≤ d that does **not** divide ℓ.             (9)

Using (8) we may (and do) choose q with  

                ½d < q ≤ d.                             (10)



--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Building a better map
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Take q vertices among the d = n-c points that do **not** lie on a
cycle and connect them into one q–cycle.
All remaining (d–q) vertices are mapped directly to one fixed point on
a cycle (so their distance to a cycle is now 1).

Call the new map σ̃.  What are its properties?

•  The behaviour of τ on C is untouched, so ord on C is still ℓ.  
•  The new q–cycle contributes the factor q to the eventual period,
   and because q ∤ ℓ we have  

                ord of the permutation part = ℓq.  
•  The longest distance to a cycle in σ̃ is at most 1.

Hence  

                L(σ̃) ≥ ℓq.                             (11)

On the other hand, from (2) and (5)

                L(τ) ≤ d + ℓ.                          (12)



--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  σ̃ beats τ
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because q ≥ ½d and q ≥ 3 (for large n) we compute

        ℓq − (ℓ+d) = ℓ(q−1) − d
                     ≥ ℓ(½d−1) − d
                     > 0                                (13)

(the last inequality uses ℓ ≥ 2 and d≫1).

Combining (11), (12) and (13) we get  

                L(σ̃) > L(τ),

contradicting the choice of τ when L(τ)=g(n).

Therefore the assumption (5) is impossible; hence every map that
achieves the maximal order satisfies d ≤ n^{0.501}.  Plugging this
into (3) gives

                g(n) ≤ f(n) + n^{0.501}.                (14)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
7.  Conclusion
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For all sufficiently large n we have proved

                g(n) < f(n)+ n^{0.501}.                 ☐



--------------------------------------------------------------------
Final answer
--------------------------------------------------------------------
For all sufficiently large n,

                g(n) \;<\; f(n)\;+\; n^{0.501}.
final:
Let  

• [n]={1,2,…,n},  
• Sₙ the set of permutations of [n],  
• Tₙ the set of all self-maps of [n].

For τ∈Tₙ write  

ord(τ)=|{τ,τ²,τ³,…}|  
(the number of distinct iterates).

Denote  

f(n)=max_{σ∈Sₙ}ord(σ),  g(n)=max_{τ∈Tₙ}ord(τ).

The goal is to prove

g(n)<f(n)+n^{0.501}   for all sufficiently large n. (∗)



1.  The shape of an arbitrary map  

For τ∈Tₙ let  

C=C(τ)= {x : x lies on a (directed) cycle of τ}, m=|C|,  
h=h(τ)= max {k≥0 : some x satisfies τ^{k}(x)∈C but τ^{k-1}(x)∉C}.  

Thus h is the largest distance of a vertex from the set of cycles
(the “height’’ of the rooted trees that feed the cycles).

After h steps every element already sits on a
cycle, so afterwards the map repeats with the period of the permutation
τ|_C.  Consequently

ord(τ) ≤ h + L,  L = lcm{lengths of the cycles of τ|_C}. (1)

Restricted to C, τ is a permutation of m points, hence

L ≤ f(m).                                                   (2)

Because there are h non-cyclic vertices on a longest path,
m ≤ n−h; moreover f is increasing, so

L ≤ f(n−h).                                                 (3)

Combining (1)–(3) we obtain, for every τ∈Tₙ,

ord(τ) ≤ Φₙ(h) := h + f(n−h),  0 ≤ h ≤ n.                 (4)



2.  Landau’s estimate  

A classical result of Landau states that for every ε>0 there is N(ε)
such that for all m ≥ N(ε)

exp((1−ε)√{m log m}) ≤ f(m) ≤ exp((1+ε)√{m log m}).        (5)

Fix ε=¼ and assume n ≥ N:=N(¼).



3.  Bounding Φₙ(h) when h is small  

If h ≤ n^{0.501} then from (4)

Φₙ(h) ≤ f(n) + n^{0.501}.                                   (6)



4.  Bounding Φₙ(h) when h is large  

Henceforth assume h ≥ n^{0.501}.  

We first prove that

f(n) ≥ h·f(n−h).                                            (7)

Using (5),

log f(n) − log f(n−h)
 ≥ ¾(√{n log n} − √{(n−h) log(n−h)})                     (8)

Put g(t)=√{t log t}.  For x≥1,

g'(x)= (log x +1)/(2√{x log x}) ≥ (½)√{log x}/√x.

Therefore

g(n)−g(n−h) = ∫_{n-h}^n g'(x)dx
             ≥ ½√{log(n−h)} ∫_{n-h}^n dx/√x
             = ½√{log(n−h)}·2(√n−√{n−h})
             ≥ h√{log(n-h)}/(2√n).                       (9)

Because h ≥ n^{0.501}, we have h/√n ≥ n^{0.001}.  Hence the right–hand
side of (9) is at least c n^{0.001}√{log n} for a fixed c>0, and for
large n this quantity exceeds log h (indeed, log h ≤ log n).
Combining (8) and (9) we get

log f(n) − log f(n−h) > log h, whence f(n) ≥ h f(n−h).     (10)

Now

Φₙ(h)=h+f(n−h) ≤ h + f(n)/h ≤ f(n) + h
                        ≤ f(n)+n^{0.501}.                 (11)



5.  Maximising Φₙ(h)  

From (6) and (11) we have Φₙ(h) ≤ f(n)+n^{0.501} for every 0≤h≤n,
so by (4)

g(n)=max_{τ∈Tₙ}ord(τ) ≤ max_{0≤h≤n}Φₙ(h) ≤ f(n)+n^{0.501}. (12)

Because both g(n) and f(n) are integers, inequality (12) is in fact
strict once n≥N.



6.  Conclusion  

There exists N₀ such that for all n ≥ N₀

g(n) < f(n) + n^{0.501},

which is exactly inequality (∗).

Final answer.
